title: I received a summons from Midland Funding for a credit card bill they say they bought from Citibank for $1500 . How do I respond
question: to the summons? They never contacted me and they only sent the summons, nothing proving that it's actually a legitimate bill. It just says I owe money for a credit card and show only the last 4 digits of an account. I need to respond and I need to do this pro per so any help would be greatly appreciated. Do I file the general denial from http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/pld050.pdf ? I'm a little confused because it say it the amount needs to be under 1,000 but my summons says 1594.00 Thanks
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Debt settlement,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Sued for debt,Fees
answers:
you need to respond to the complaint. I have handled numerous cases against Midland Funding. The amount they are seeking is the principal sum plus they will seek interest, court costs, and attorney fees.

Kevin Sullivan
415-441-1052

You don't say whether the bill is yours or not, or whether you owe money on the credit card. Give the attorney a call, and see what they want. If the bill is truly yours, you may want to negotiate some sort of deal with them.

Midland is a debt buyer and if you didn't pay your credit card bill then yes they can sue you. Most people in your situation have numerous debts not just a single card. The lawsuit may be the first of many. Consult with a bk attorney or sent settlement attorney in your area.

Use Answer--Contract #PLD-C-010, same website, and that should get you to the next stage. Consult a local attorney as to how best to present any defenses available to you.
